p: Officials and experts compared similarities and differences of the acronyms and believed that they are all novel and impactful syndromes. They may have fever, respiratory symptoms, history of contact or travel, an animal vector and a novel coronavirus, and significant mortality and morbidity. There are relatively minimal or no differences in these acronyms except for the nomenclatures (Table 1). The fact that a significant number of patients with COVID‐19 are mildly symptomatic vs patients with SARS and MERS, with low mortality rates, reflects that SARS‐CoV‐2 resembles other common circulating respiratory viruses. However, the lack of any population immunity against SARS‐CoV‐2 gives it the ability to cause high attack rates, which can overwhelm and cripple healthcare systems if not managed carefully.
